channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Residents Flee Town Near Nuclear Site as Shelling Continues
item.description: Artillery fire resumed from the direction of the Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia complex, where fears of a nuclear accident are rising. Elsewhere, Ukraine’s military denounced Russia’s apparent plans to try captured soldiers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A broken window in the town of Marhanets on Sunday, after what residents say was Russian shelling overnight from the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant. People are fleeing a town near the plant, Enerhodar.

item.title: Japanese Photographer Blows Whistle on Treatment of ‘Comfort Women’
item.description: While Tsukasa Yajima has won praise for exposing problems at South Korea’s best-known shelter for former sex slaves, he has also been the focus of intense backlash.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Japanese photographer Tsukasa Yajima standing in front of portraits he took of former sex slaves at a nursing facility and museum in Gwangju, South Korea, where four of the women live.

item.title: His Next Move: A Ukrainian Boy Starts a New Life Through Chess
item.description: After fleeing the war in Ukraine with his mother, Maksym Kryshtafor, 8, is using his passion for chess to help him assimilate into the United Kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Mary Turner

item.title: Eight Injured in Shooting in Jerusalem
item.description: Two of the victims were seriously hurt by gunfire outside the Old City. Israeli authorities described the incident as a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Maya Alleruzzo/Associated Press
item.media:description: The scene of a shooting early Sunday near the Old City of Jerusalem.

item.title: Shots Fired at Airport in Australia’s Capital
item.description: There were no reports of injuries, but the episode was nonetheless shocking in a country where mass and random shootings are extremely rare.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Australian Federal Police on the scene after a man fired gunshots at Canberra Airport on Sunday.

item.title: Salman Rushdie Attack Recalls Murder of His Japanese Translator
item.description: Hitoshi Igarashi, who translated “The Satanic Verses,” was fatally stabbed at a university near Tokyo where he taught Islamic culture. The crime remains unsolved.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Chautauqua Institute in New York State, where the author Salman Rushdie was attacked on Friday.

item.title: Ivory Coast, a Big Cocoa Exporter, Tries to Move Up the Ladder
item.description: A new generation of Ivory Coast chocolatiers is striving to change an industry that has long left cocoa farmers in poverty.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Andrew Caballero-Reynolds
item.media:credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tano Adgawa Jediqual, and Kuaku Amwe peel the shells off roasted cocoa beans in the Coopbel cooperative before being packaged for processing in Toumodi.

item.title: The Tumultuous Summer That Changed the World
item.description: Over the span of just a few weeks in 2021, the Taliban’s offensive shifted from rural threat to urban conquest before they walked into Kabul on Aug. 15. Times photographers were there to document that fateful summer in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban fighters in Kabul, Afghanistan, on the day the government collapsed.

item.title: After Years of Languishing in Egypt’s Prisons, a Sudden Release
item.description: Political prisoners in Egypt live under constant uncertainty about how long they will be detained. So freedom often comes as a big, and welcome, surprise.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Amr Abdallah Dalsh/Reuters
item.media:description: Kholoud Said, a translator and researcher at the famed Great Library of Alexandria, was released from Tora prison in June. Ms. Said was first arrested in April 2020 after writing posts critical of the government on Facebook.

item.title: In Wealthy City, a Marxist Mayor Wins Over Voters
item.description: Yes, this Communist politician in Graz, Austria, wants to redistribute wealth, but a focus on housing, her own modest lifestyle and a hard childhood have helped her popularity.
item.dc:creator: Denise Hruby
item.media:credit: Marylise Vigneau for The New York Times
item.media:description: The iconic bell tower in the wealthy city of Graz, Austria, which is led by a Communist mayor, Elke Kahr.

item.title: How Sri Lankans Rose Up to Dethrone a Dynasty
item.description: An army of nuns, farmers and middle-class professionals felt a duty to save their virtually bankrupt nation. But their fight is far from over.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Emily Schmall and Atul Loke
item.media:credit: Atul Loke For The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters celebrating last month in Colombo, Sri Lanka, after the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa.

item.title: ‘My School Had No Chairs, No Blackboards, No Books’
item.description: Despite her struggles to get an education in Afghanistan, Mursal Rahim holds fast to her dream of becoming a lawyer.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mursal Rahim in the bedroom she shares with her two sisters in their home in Houston.

item.title: ‘Day by Day, I Realized I Have the Freedom Here’
item.description: A group of Afghan employees from the Kabul bureau of The New York Times adjust after evacuation to the United States. Their new lives are challenging, but full of opportunities.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Blumenstein
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mursal and Marwa Rahim in their new home in Houston, talking over FaceTime with their cousin, Zerghona, who is in Turkey.

item.title: ‘Regimes Like the Taliban That Impose Themselves on Nations Will Not Last Long’
item.description: Omar Ahmadi graduated from university with a degree in international relations, after evacuating from Afghanistan. He hopes to continue his studies in the United States.
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Omar Ahmadi, 26, whose father was the longtime chef of The New York Times Kabul Bureau, outside the apartment building where he and his family live in Alexandria, Va.

item.title: An Orchestra Supports Ukraine, and Reunites a Couple Parted by War
item.description: “I don’t have a gun, but I have my cello,” a musician says as he joins the Ukrainian Freedom Orchestra, which is made up of refugees who fled the war and artists who stayed behind.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Musicians from Ukraine shortly after they crossed the border into Poland, on their way to meet up with the musicians forming the Ukrainian Freedom Orchestra, a new ensemble touring Europe and the United States to rally support for Ukraine.

item.title: How Frustration Over TikTok Has Mounted in Washington
item.description: National security concerns over the Chinese-owned viral video app remain unresolved. Lawmakers and regulators are increasingly pushing for action.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Thomas Suen/Reuters
item.media:description: A security guard at an office of ByteDance, the Chinese internet company that owns TikTok, in Beijing in 2020.

item.title: As U.S. Seeks to Close Guantánamo, Saudi Center Could Be Option
item.description: The Biden administration is looking for places to safely send cleared Guantánamo detainees who cannot go home. Could a program in Saudi Arabia provide a solution?
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg and Gabriella Demczuk
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Staff members at the Counseling and Care Center in Riyadh. About 6,000 men have gone through some form of the re-education program for former extremists, including 137 former prisoners of Guantánamo Bay.

item.title: Partition Survivors Seek Closure Through a YouTube Channel
item.description: The YouTube channel Punjabi Lehar, based in Pakistan, has reunited people who were separated by the partition of India in 1947.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nasir Dhillon, right, and his assistants at the studio for Mr. Dhillon’s YouTube channel in Faisalabad, Pakistan.

item.title: With New Weaponry, Ukraine Is Subtly Shifting Its War Strategy
item.description: Striking deep behind enemy lines, the Ukrainians are depleting Russia’s combat potential, slowing its advance in the east and creating new vulnerabilities in the south.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke rising after a strike on a Russian military base near Novofedorivka, in Crimea, on Tuesday. Ukraine is exploiting its new capacity to strike deep behind enemy lines to deplete Russia’s combat potential.

item.title: Summer’s Down Elevator
item.description: Make the most of the last weeks of summer, whether you’re dreading the end of the season or dancing about it.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Restaurants That Are Institutions as Much as Places to Dine
item.description: Edmonton’s Bistro Praha is among the rare spots to find a formula that has ensured longevity in a generally difficult business.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Edmonton’s Bistro Praha has long been a hangout for artists and performers.

item.title: American Lawyer Asim Ghafoor Freed From Detention in U.A.E.
item.description: Asim Ghafoor, who was convicted of financial crimes, was freed from a monthlong detention in Dubai after paying a $1.36 million fine.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Asim Ghafoor in 2008 in Washington, where he works. He had been detained in the United Arab Emirates since mid-July.

item.title: Aid helps Ukraine achieve ‘outweighed gains.’
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit firing toward Russian infantry troops advancing around the eastern Ukrainian town of Pokrovske on Wednesday.

item.title: Shelling of Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Raises Fears and Outrage
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russia of “nuclear blackmail” as the two sides traded blame.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant this month.

item.title: Russian Attack in Kramatorsk Kills 2 civilians, Regional Military Leader Says
item.description: A video showed damaged homes and some areas that had been turned into ruins.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian attack on Kramatorsk on Friday left two civilians dead and more than a dozen others injured.

item.title: Kenya on Edge as Media’s Election Tally Suddenly Stops
item.description: An attempt at radical transparency by the election commission, which uploaded raw ballot numbers online, led to divergent tallies. “People are so tense that they cannot even think straight.”
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Motorcycle taxi drivers watching live news on television for updates on the presidential election, in Kisumu, Kenya, on Friday.

item.title: Climate Bill Heads to Biden’s Desk. There Is More to Be Done.
item.description: The bill will cut U.S. emissions, but not nearly enough. It’s “like losing 20 pounds when you need to lose 100 pounds” one expert said.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Young climate activists say they worry the new tax and climate law will lead to a complacent electorate that believes climate change is solved, when in fact the government has only taken the first necessary steps.

item.title: Reflections on U.S. Withdrawal From Afghanistan
item.description: They watched, waited and tried to help as the Afghan capital fell to the Taliban last year. “It was traumatic,” one said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times

item.title: Montenegro Gunman Kills 10 Before Being Shot and Killed
item.description: The first to be killed were two children and their mother, tenants of the gunman. Witnesses said the gunman then started randomly shooting at passers-by, killing seven and wounding six.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Dogramadzieva
item.media:credit: Boris Pejovic/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A crime scene investigator carrying a rifle believed to have been used in a mass shooting on Friday in Cetinje, Montenegro.

item.title: Protests Turn Deadly in Sierra Leone Over Rising Cost of Living
item.description: Clashes between protesters and security forces over rising fuel and food prices have left an unknown number dead, and the government has imposed a nationwide curfew.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Jaime Yaya Barry
item.media:credit: Umaru Fofana/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers patrolled the streets of Freetown, Sierra Leone, during an anti-government protest on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukrainian Children Bring a Play From a Bomb Shelter to Brooklyn
item.description: The group recently arrived in New York to perform “Mom on Skype,” first staged in April in Lviv, at the Irondale Center this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hanna Oneshchak, 12, playing the accordion, with other Ukrainian students during rehearsals for their play.

item.title: Here are the risks as shelling continues at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: Russian forces seized the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, Europe’s largest, in March.

item.title: How the Taliban Has Rolled Back the Clock Since Seizing Power
item.description: Nearly a year since the Taliban seized power, new restrictions have reshaped the social fabric. Schools and jobs are again off-limits for women, music has been banned, and beards are mandatory for men — just like in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, David Zucchino and The New York Times
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A year since the Taliban seized power, two decades of U.S.-financed reforms have been reversed by mounting restrictions on daily life.

item.title: ‘We Are the Flour Between Two Millstones’
item.description: Struggling to build a new life in the U.S., one Times reporter examines how a traumatic year has changed lives both physically and emotionally.
item.dc:creator: Fahim Abed
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fahim Abed in Houston last year.

item.title: ‘I Plan to Encourage and Inspire Women With My Success’
item.description: Marwa Rahim’s hopes of a career in medicine were interrupted by the Taliban takeover. Now she is determined to resume her studies.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marwa Rahim at a mall in Houston.

item.title: ‘In the United States, I Feel Optimistic’
item.description: As a child, Samira Rustami was discouraged from reading. But she studied business administration in Afghanistan, and now hopes to go into nursing.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Samira Rustami, 20, with her 1-month-old daughter, Durrin, at their home in Houston.

item.title: What Happens If Shelling Continues at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant?
item.description: Repeated shelling inside the plant’s complex over the past seven days has stirred new concerns of a nuclear accident.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: Russian forces seized the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, Europe’s largest, in March.

item.title: Estonia never needed to import gas by ship, until now.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Marta Giaccone for The New York Times
item.media:description: A floating facility in Estonia will take in shipments of natural gas and pipe it to a network that serves the Baltics and Finland.

item.title: Russia’s Economy Contracts Sharply as War and Sanctions Take Hold
item.description: The country’s gross domestic product from April through June declined 4 percent from a year earlier, new government data shows.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson and Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Yuri Kochetkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Shoppers in Moscow. The Russian economy has proved more resilient to sanctions than some economists initially expected, but experts now predict a downturn.

item.title: A 1,300-Pound Walrus Could Be Killed if She Endangers the Public
item.description: Freya has been lounging on boats and eating mussels in Norway, but authorities have started to worry about her presence.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Tor Erik Schrder/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Freya, a young female walrus, rested on a boat in Frognerkilen in the Oslo Fjord of Norway in July.

item.title: Five State-Run Chinese Giants to Delist From U.S. Stock Exchanges
item.description: The companies, collectively worth hundreds of billions of dollars, issued a flurry of statements amid tensions between Beijing and Washington over regulation and broader political issues.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Three of the world’s biggest energy companies, including Sinopec, said they would apply to delist their American shares.

item.title: What I’m Reading
item.description: An old favorite and a cli-fi future.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The English novelist Jane Austen as depicted in a family portrait.

item.title: Gerhard Schröder, Germany’s former leader, sues Parliament over perks that he lost because of ties to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gerhard Schröder, the former German chancellor, has kept up his friendship with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Drought Is Declared in Parts of a Hot, Dry Britain
item.description: The announcement by the government will allow water companies to tighten conservation measures. Extreme-heat warnings have also been issued for parts of southern England and Wales.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: The grass in many of London’s parks has dried out after a summer of record-breaking temperatures and little rain.

item.title: How the Climate Bill Will Make Cleaner Energy Cheaper
item.description: The climate bill will make cleaner energy cheaper for everyone.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: Solar panels in Grafton, Mass.

item.title: You Just Can’t Get the Staff
item.description: Australia’s labor and skills shortage has affected almost every sector. Signs of it are everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant in Sydney earlier this year. Australia’s labor and skills shortage has affected almost every sector, including food service.

item.title: Why are Russia and Turkey growing so close? Putin needs allies, and Erdogan needs bolstering.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Murat Kula/Turkish Presidential Press Service via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Sochi, Russia, last Friday, for their second face-to-face talks in three weeks.

item.title: Greece’s Mitsotakis Fends Off Accusations His Government Spied on Rivals
item.description: Revelations that the cellphone of a top opposition politician was tapped have shaken the government and stoked concerns over just how widespread such surveillance is.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Thanassis Stavrakis/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece in May. His government has been accused of spying on its political rivals.

item.title: U.N. Ship to Carry Ukrainian Grain Directly to Horn of Africa
item.description: It is the first ship hired to carry the grain to countries badly affected by food shortages since a deal between Ukraine and Russia allowed shipments to resume.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain silos at the Odesa Port in Odesa, Ukraine, in July.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Moves by the U.S. to unseal the Mar-a-Lago search warrant.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland.

item.title: Serbia’s Leader Rejects Putin Label Amid Fears of Russian Meddling
item.description: President Aleksandar Vucic’s ties to Moscow raise awkward questions as the Kremlin appears to be stirring unrest in the Balkans to deflect attention from the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandar Vucic in the library of the presidential palace in Belgrade, the Serbian capital, this month. “We are not interested in expanding our borders and getting into any fights with our neighbors,” he said.

item.title: Shelling Threatens Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant, and U.N. Pleads for Access
item.description: The chief U.N. nuclear monitor called for an immediate stop to fighting that risks a radiation disaster, as Russians and Ukrainians blamed each other for strikes dangerously close to the reactors.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas and Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A Russian military convoy on the road to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in May.

item.title: How the war changed a Kyiv museum’s view of its past.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago

item.title: Heavy Losses Leave Russia Short of Its Goal, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The estimated deaths and injuries are stalling Russia’s progress in eastern Ukraine, military experts say, as fighting intensifies in the south.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of a tank in the Chernihiv region of Ukraine. U.S. officials estimate that 500 Russian troops are killed or wounded every day in Ukraine.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: U.S. to Unseal Trump Warrant
item.description: Plus Russia prepares for show trials and Taiwan does not rise to China’s provocations.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland had come under pressure to provide more information about the search at former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home.

item.title: Rhythm of War: A Thunderous Blast, and Then a Coffee Break
item.description: This is a war fought in a cycle of opposites: bursts of chaos from outgoing and incoming shelling, and then long lulls in which soldiers undertake the most routine activities.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit firing from a frontline position near the town of Bakhmut on Wednesday.

item.title: Don’t Blame Monkeys for Monkeypox, W.H.O. Says After Attacks
item.description: The outbreak is centered on humans, not animals, health officials said, after a report that some monkeys were harmed in São Paulo, Brazil, out of fear of transmission, according to local authorities.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Marcelo Sayo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A monkey at Lage Park in Rio de Janeiro. At least 10 monkeys were rescued in São Paulo, Brazil, after they appeared to have been attacked or poisoned, the police there said.

item.title: All Hooting Aside: Did a Vocal Evolution Give Rise to Language?
item.description: The loss of certain muscles in the human larynx may have helped give our species a voice, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Nature Picture Library/Alamy
item.media:description: A study of more than three dozen primates found that they all possessed an extra set of vocal membranes in the larynx, just above the vocal cords. Only humans lack the structure.

item.title: Italy Salutes a War Hero and the Values He Fought For
item.description: Mario Fiorentini, Italy’s most decorated resistance fighter, died at age 103 this week, and his mourners want his legacy to live on.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Fiorentini family
item.media:description: Mr. Fiorentini when he was in his 20s.

item.title: Palestinian Prisoners in Israel Use Hunger Strikes to Seek Freedom
item.description: For decades, Palestinians imprisoned by Israel have used these protests as a way to demand better living conditions and an end to indefinite detentions.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kayed al-Fasfos at his home in the West Bank in April. He was released from an Israeli prison after a 131-day hunger strike. “Even if I had died,” he said, “I would consider it a victory because in the end I left the prison.”

item.title: The New ‘Monuments Officers’ Prepare to Protect Art Amid War
item.description: A group of art experts have had intensive training to become part of the U.S. Army Reserve. It will be their job to help save cultural heritage in war zones.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Greg Kahn for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Army’s Monuments Officers in training. They will work in a military capacity to identify and preserve cultural treasures around the world that are threatened by conflict, just like the Monuments Men of World War II.
